generif.text: expression of PRAME is an indicator of favorable prognosis and could be a useful tool for monitoring minimal residual disease in childhood AML.
PRAME gene expression in childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia
PRAME is highly expressed in primary advanced neuroblastoma
The overexpression of PRAME protein frequently observed in human cancers confers growth or survival advantages by antagonizing retinoic acid receptor(RAR) signaling.

The results suggest that the analysis of PRAME protein may contribute for the distinction between normal and leukemic cells in chronic lymphoproliferative disorders(CLD), and that PRAME may be a potential target for therapy.
PRAME is expressed in acute myeloblastic leukaemia
Overexpression of PRAME was associated with childhood acute leukemia

PRAME is detected in one third of the cases with CLs. PRAME mRNA changes may be detected during the progression of these disorders and/or after therapy. PRAME mRNA may be a useful marker to detect the minimal residual disease and the response to therapy.
hypomethylation of PRAME up-regulates its expression in CML and might play a significant role in the progression of the disease
Changes in the methylation pattern in defined parts of the regulatory regions of PRAME are sufficient for its upregulation in cells usually not expressing the gene.
PRAME mRNA expression may be a useful prognostic and predictive marker for breast cancer.
PRAME expression is not associated with down-regulation of retinoic acid signaling in primary acute myeloid leukemia.
PRAME expression in acute leukemia may be a useful marker to detect the minimal residual disease and to determine the response to therapy in acute leukemia patients.
PRAME gene was overexpressed in adult acute leukemia patients and leukemia cell-lines.
We conclude that HCL and CLL differ in PRAME overexpression, and that basal normal expression of PRAME may limit its usefulness for following patients with minimal residual CLL or HCL.
Loss of PRAME is associated with childhood acute myeloid leukemia.
The significant inverse correlation between the degree of methylation and PRAME expression suggests a causal role of DNA methylation in PRAME regulation.

Multivariable analysis indicated that PRAME is an independent marker of shortened metastasis-free interval in patients who did not receive adjuvant chemotherapy. PRAME expression was associated with tumour grade and negative oestrogen receptor status
the 4 biomarkers CLU, ITGB3, PRAME and CAPG may be used as prognostic factors for patients with stage III serous ovarian adenocarcinomas.
Low PRAME expression defines a subgroup of patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia with a short relapse-free survival

quantified both WT1 and PRAME transcript levels in the bone marrow of AML patients. Dynamic patterns of WT1 and PRAME during follow-up showed that a consistent elevation or a rise over time to exceed the normal range predicted clinical relapse

E2F4, PHACTR3, PRAME family member and CDH12 most probably play important role in non-small-cell lung cancer geneses
PRAME expression in DLBCL correlates with response to anthracycline containing chemotherapy.
PRAME inhibits myeloid differentiation in certain myeloid leukemias, and that its function in these cells is lineage and phenotype dependent.
The PRAME transcript was highly expressed in acute myeloid leukemia patients and was a favorable marker of prognosis.
The level of prame gene transcript increases in chronic myeloid leukemia which associates with disease progression.

Results showed the expression of MCSP and PRAME in conjunctival melanoma and benign conjunctival nevi and showed that MCSP and PRAME were differentially expressed in both and can help to differentiate the lesions diagnostically.
PRAME may be involved in the tumorigenic process in a wide range of cancers, at least in part by blocking the tumor suppressor pathway mediated by TRAIL expression.

The cytotoxic activity of our PRAME-specific CTLs was directed not only against leukemic blasts, but also against leukemic progenitor cells as assessed by colony-forming-inhibition assays, which have been implicated in leukemia relapse.
the expansion of the PRAME family occurred in both autosomes and sex chromosomes
PRAME plays an important role in disease progression in acute leukemia.

The authors applied protein-complex purification strategies and identified PRAME as a substrate recognition subunit of a Cullin2-based E3 ubiquitin ligase.
Studies suggest that activated human gammadelta T cells can efficiently present PRAME and STEAP1-derived epitopes and allow breaking tolerance against these tumor-associated self-antigens.
PRAME effectively differentiates mullerian carcinoma from malignant mesothelioma at the mRNA and protein levels.
NYESO-1/LAGE-1s and PRAME are targets for antigen specific T cells in chondrosarcoma following treatment with 5-Aza-2-deoxycitabine
these results suggest that PRAME plays an important role in cell proliferation and disease progression in osteosarcoma.
PRAME expression is regulated at the epigenetic level. For this reason inhibitors of DNA methylation, such as 5-azacytidine, can modulate the expression of this tumor associated antigen.
a novel link between the oncoprotein PRAME and the conserved EKC complex
PRAME as biomarkers for solid tumor
PRAME and WT1 transcripts constitute a good molecular marker combination for monitoring minimal residual disease in MDS.
The complex PRAME/EZH2 is able to repress TRAIL expression, in a cancer-specific manner; inhibition of PRAME/EZH2 releases apoptosis-mediating TRAIL. (Review)

PRAME impairs differentiation and increases proliferation likely via blocking retinoic acid receptor signaling.

PRAME and its paralogs are leucine rich repeat proteins. Structure predictions suggest PRAME resembles the extracellular domains of TLR3 and TLR4, or intracellular NALP family. This suggests PRAME may have a role in sensing Pathogen Associated Molecular Patterns (PAMPs).

PRAME expression in leukaemic cell lines is upregulated by IFN gamma and LPS, suggesting a possible role in immune responses. PRAME associates with Elongin BC complexes by binding Elongin C, and co-localises to the Golgi network. Nuclear PRAME interacts with Histone H3. The results suggest that PRAME has dual roles in gene regulation in the nucleus and protein turnover trafficking in the Golgi
PRAME is upregulated by signalling pathways that are activated in response to infection/inflammation.
elevated PRAME expression in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
results suggested that PRAME was a predictor for better outcome, could be a useful target for immunotherapy, and might represent a candidate marker for the monitoring of minimal residual disease
This study shows the prognostic significance of PRAME expression in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma patients treated with R-CHOP therapy.

PRAME immunoreactivity in myeloid leukemia (ML) of Down syndrome (DS) is largely due to the non-blast components, while PRAME immunoreactivity in blasts of Transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM) is not restricted to cases that progress to ML of DS.
PRAME expression is considered as a poor prognostic parameter in HL.
Our results suggest that the leukemias expressing high levels of PRAME has favorable prognosis
PRAME is an independent prognostic biomarker in Uveal melanoma , which identifies increased metastatic risk in patients with Class 1 or disomy 3 tumors.
Leukemias expressing high levels of PRAME had higher levels of cell death by regulating S100A4/p53 signaling.

In line with its roles in controlling cell growth, RPAME regulates multiple critical cell-growth related genes, including IGF1R oncogene. IGF1R up-regulation contributes to increase of cell growth upon the knockdown of PRAME.
PRAME is frequently expressed in epithelial ovarian cancer at the mRNA and protein levels, and DNA methylation is a key mechanism regulating its expression.
PRAME plays a role in preventing the invasion and metastasis of lung adenocarcinoma
PRAME is a downstream factor of SOX17 and LIN28 in regulating pluripotency and suppressing somatic/germ cell differentiation in primordial germ cells, germ cell neoplasia in situ, and seminomas.
PRAME is aberrantly hypomethylated and activated in Class 1 and Class 2 uveal melanomas and is associated with increased metastatic risk in both classes

PRAME is expressed in many primary and metastatic UMs, and about half of the metastatic UMs coexpress PRAME and HLA class I.

BP.term: positive regulation of cell population proliferation
negative regulation of retinoic acid receptor signaling pathway

name: PRAME nuclear receptor transcriptional regulator
other_names: melanoma antigen preferentially expressed in tumors
summary: This gene encodes an antigen that is preferentially expressed in human melanomas and that is recognized by cytolytic T lymphocytes. It is not expressed in normal tissues, except testis. The encoded protein acts as a repressor of retinoic acid receptor, and likely confers a growth advantage to cancer cells via this function. Alternative splicing results in multiple transcript variants. [provided by RefSeq, Apr 2014].
